column4: is there a rule of thumb for partitioning sizes for /, /swap, /home, etc., in Ubuntu?
I wouldn't recommend more than 300Mb for Swap
a partition for /home is up to you, I don't have a partition for it, but some people like it best
it's been a while since I've installed a linux distro...but for some reason I remember making the swap about twice the size of the RAM. is that no longer a valid measure?
If you've got 64Mb RAM that's only 128Mb Swap... But if you have a gig ram, you *don't* need swap
I actually run my pc without swap..
that's good to know. this particular machine has 1GB RAM
You can run quite a bit on 1 gig. I run KDE+Vmware(256Mb Ram) + Azureus (java) and still got 500mb free
if I do some heavy image manipulation or video editing, I will need some swap space, though
Maybe... But, as I said, too much swap will *kill* your perfomance
remember that swap is "false ram"
yes, but it won't be used unless the RAM isn't available, right?
Depends on swappiness, but in general, it won't.
sounds good. another question that I didn't see in the wiki: is there a problem w/ large SATA hd? (250GB)
I don't know... It shouldn't be... I'm running a 160Gb SATA (boot from there, too)
I'm using ntfs-3g. Works quite well. Supposedly it's beta software, so if you REALLY care about your files, you better not use it. But I been using it for a week or two now, It works great.
Had to do a chkdsk on windows one time, but only for a silly error
I can't remember what I was using a year ago (it, too, came with warnings :) ), but the shared NTFS partition will contain mostly media files (images, video, some text, etc.)
